abstract.text: The PK model is based on a recently validated, three-compartment model [2] , which calculates the volume of distribution of each compartment, the central clearance, and the inter-compartmental clearances. These results are used as input into the general three-compartment linear elimination framework [1], which uses the volumes and clearances to determine the value of several intermediate variables. Depending on the method of delivery and administration procedure chosen, these intermediate variables determine the overall concentration of propofol in the blood. The performance of the PK model has been shown to be acceptable for clinical usage [2] .

In our model, propofol is assumed to be administered via infusion. Since clinicians may need to manipulate the blood concentration of propofol to induce a change in respiratory drive, a multidose linear elimination framework is used. When patients are still undergoing propofol infusion, the concentration of propofol in their blood at time t, C(t), is given by [2]

body_text.text: The variables A, α, B, β, C and γ are the intermediate variables calculated using patient parameters. The control parameters -propofol dose rate (D i ), time at which dose was given (t Di ), and total infusion time (T inf ) -can be changed by the clinician to adjust a patient's propofol concentration. This equation considers up to n changes in propofol dosage, indexed by i. After infusion discontinuation, the residual concentration of propofol in a patient's blood can be estimated by a separate equation [2] :

To determine the peak flow and hence V T H , we employed an additional equation [5] , derived from the general equation of motion of the respiratory system [3] . This equation, validated in the clinical setting [4] , is based on a single first-order differential equation to represent respiratory motion during inspiration and assumes linear pressure-volume and pressure-flow relations during inspiration. Patient's flow (V (t)) is represented as a function of time (t) by the equation [5]

and can be seen to be a function of a patient's respiratory muscle pressure (P mus ), their inspiratory time per breath (T i , derived from the patient's inspiratory:expiratory ratio and time per breath), P SV , R and E RS . To determine the peak flow, the first-order optimality condition of equation (3) must be satisfied. Setting the derivative ofV (t) to 0 determines the time at which peak flow is reached (t max ). Inserting t max into equation (3) then yields the patient's peak flow (V (t max )). The flow-cycle threshold is then taken to be a proportion (x T H ) of this peak flow:

Thus, in the LDPV model, x T H acts as a control parameter which clinicians can adjust to modify the flow-cycle threshold. We show in 3 that for relevant patient parameters, t max is a unique stationary point andV (t max ) is concave, thus making t max a maximum ofV (t).

To ensure t max is the time at which peak flow is reached, it is necessary to check if the secondorder optimality condition is satisfied. Taking the second derivative of equation (3) and using t = t max results in equation (5).
body_text.section: Second-order Optimality Condition for Peak Flow

body_text.text: From equation (5), for clinically relevant values of P mus , E RS , T i , R and t max , the following can be observed:

body_text.text: For peak flow to be achieved at t max , dV (t max ) dt 2 ≤ 0. This condition is satisfied with either of the following cases.

body_text.text: The general LDPV model uses patient-specific clinician-controlled parameters and provides output measures that can be used to determine if the intervention is safe with respect to lung stress (determined by ∆P L ), diaphragm stress (determined by ∆P ES ), and pH level. Because all of the components are interrelated, as shown in Figure 1 (main text), the mathematical equations connecting all of them need to be solved simultaneously, with the exception of the propofol pharmacokinetics model, which can be solved independently because it does not require any input from the other components.
The outputs of the model are calculated using the following steps:
1. The propofol pharmacokinetic equations are solved using patient-specific parameters to generate a propofol concentration.

2. The propofol concentration, patient-specific parameters and ventilator controls (see Table 1 , main text) are used as inputs for the rest of the model. Since the ventilator, blood acidbase, respiratory drive and respiratory system mechanics are closely linked, they are solved simultaneously to obtain key intermediate variables.

body_text.section: The resulting intermediate variables are applied to equations

body_text.text: to calculate ∆P L and ∆P ES . pH is obtained from the calculated [H + ] value.
body_text.section: The resulting intermediate variables are applied to equations

body_text.text: The propofol pharmacokinetics model can be solved analytically using equations (1) and (2). To obtain the intermediate variables for the remainder of the system, multiple nonlinear equations are solved numerically using a modified Newton's method, given initial estimates of the intermediate variable values. The system attempts to minimize the error on consecutive estimations for all the variables listed in Table 2 of the main text, until the error associated with each one is below the tolerance level (1.48 · 10 −8 ). Thus, the condition for solving the model as a whole occurs when the maximum of the errors falls below the tolerance level. The exact number of equations that were solved depended on the mode of ventilation (23 equations under pressure support and 21 equations under proportional assist).
